The work required isolations, drain ‑ down, verification of zero ‑ energy, and confirmation that all personnel were clear before opening the system. While preparing for the final verification, one operator left the immediate area to search for a missing hose clamp without informing the lead technician. When the team began the pre ‑ entry headcount before breaking containment, one worker could not be located. Radio calls went unanswered due to the worker having set the radio on a nearby cart while checking equipment. Concerned that the operator may have re ‑ entered the barricaded zone or approached the system while residual pressure remained, the team initiated the missing ‑ person protocol and halted isolations. The operator was later found in an adjacent storage area retrieving hardware. No exposure or system breach occurred, but the temporary uncertainty stopped all work and triggered emergency standby. What could have happened Worker could have encountered residual chemical vapors from incomplete isolation. Potential for line movement or unexpected pressure release during flush. Unauthorized proximity to the transfer manifold could have resulted in splashes or inhalation exposure. Crew might have initiated containment opening without full accountability. Why did it happen – Root causes Inadequate location ‑ tracking process for tasks requiring staged isolation and verification. Communication system not designed for mandatory radio carriage during chemical ‑ handling operations. Insufficient integration of personnel ‑ accountability steps into the flush procedure. Causal factors Worker left the zone during a critical step without performing required verbal check ‑ out. High noise levels reduced ability to hear verbal calls. Time pressure to complete line flush before turnaround activities. Poor visibility around the manifold due to portable barriers and equipment congestion. Radio charging setup encouraged operators to remove devices rather than swap batteries. What went well Crew initiated a stop ‑ work immediately after failed headcount. Barricades prevented any worker from unintentionally approaching the active manifold. Supervisor escalated quickly and activated the missing ‑ person protocol. Chemical isolation valves remained locked, preventing accidental drain ‑ down. Operator was found quickly due to coordinated search actions. The task required accessing instruments located near a guardrail segment that had been temporarily removed for unrelated structural work. This change was noted in the work log but was not highlighted during the morning briefing. While repositioning a portable calibrator, one technician stepped backward to gain a better viewing angle and unknowingly moved within less than one metre of the unprotected edge. The second technician noticed the position deviation and immediately called for a stop. Work halted, and the exposed edge was barricaded before calibration proceeded. No fall occurred, but the proximity to the open edge represented a high ‑ potential incident. What could have happened Technician could have stepped into the unprotected opening and fallen approximately three metres to the level below. Secondary impact with piping or structural members could have resulted in severe injury. Dropped tools could have struck workers passing beneath the platform. Emergency response activation and work stoppage across the area. Why did it happen – Root causes Change in platform configuration was not integrated into the official access ‑ control or work ‑ at ‑ height procedure. Pre ‑ task hazard assessment lacked verification of temporary modifications in the work zone. Communication gaps between structural maintenance and instrumentation teams. Causal factors Technician focused on instrument display and not on edge awareness. Poor lighting near the removed guardrail reduced depth perception. The portable calibrator cart limited maneuverability, encouraging backwards movement. Morning briefing emphasized technical steps but did not cover updated area hazards. What went well Partner intervention occurred immediately when the unsafe position was observed. Stop ‑ work authority was exercised without hesitation. PPE (lanyards and harnesses) was available, even though the area was not initially categorized as requiring tie ‑ off. Temporary barricades were deployed quickly once the hazard was recognized. Lessons to prevent re-occurrence Always reassess hazard controls whenever access conditions change, even if unrelated to the primary task. verification: Risk register updates Employee Trips Over Laptop Cord and Falls Against Filing Cabinet Category: Incident Risk Level: Medium Setting: Corporate Office – Shared Work Area Date: 2023 Location: Vancouver Injury Category: First Aid Severity: Minor Primary Classification: Health and Safety What happened An employee in a shared office area was preparing for a virtual meeting and temporarily stretched their laptop’s power cord across the walkway to reach a wall outlet. While returning to their desk with printed materials, the employee’s foot caught the cord, causing them to stumble forward and fall against an open filing cabinet drawer. The impact resulted in a minor bruise on the hip and a small cut on the hand from contact with the drawer edge. Nearby coworkers assisted the employee, and first aid staff treated the injury on site. The area was secured until the tripping hazard and open drawer were addressed. What could have happened A fall with greater force could have caused a sprained wrist, fracture, or head injury. A coworker could have tripped on the same cord, creating multiple injuries. The fall could have damaged electronic equipment or pulled the laptop from the desk. Contact with the sharp corner of the filing cabinet could have resulted in deeper lacerations. Why did it happen – Root causes Workspace layout not designed for temporary equipment use: Limited accessible outlets led employees to improvise power setups. Inadequate hazard identification for office tasks: The employee did not assess walking paths before setting up the laptop. Lack of clear housekeeping expectations in shared spaces: Open drawers and trailing cords were not treated as active hazards. Causal factors Time pressure to join a meeting reduced attention to housekeeping. The filing cabinet had been left open by another team member retrieving files. High foot ‑ traffic area increased the likelihood of interaction with the cord. No cable management accessories available nearby. Cyber Intrusion Causes Unsafe Pressure Surge in Utility Line Category: Near Miss Risk Level: High Setting: Gas Distribution Header – Automated Pressure Control Date: 2024 Location: Canada Injury Category: No Injury Severity: Potentially Significant Primary Classification: Security What happened A process utility line supplying clean compressed gas to multiple production units was operating normally under automatic control. The pressure controller received feedback from a transmitter and modulated a control valve through a PLC. During a routine shift, operators observed the header pressure rising steadily, followed by a sudden spike that exceeded the normal operating envelope. Attempts to move the system into manual control were rejected by the interface. Field technicians confirmed the valve remained fully open despite operator commands to close. Investigation revealed that an unauthorized remote login had accessed the engineering workstation. A malicious script executed shortly after the login pushed a forced ‑ open command to the pressure valve, bypassing the controller’s internal limit logic. Operators closed upstream manual block valves and vented the header through a controlled relief line. The pressure gradually stabilized, and no equipment damage or injuries occurred. The compromised workstation was isolated and the PLC returned to normal configuration. What could have happened Overpressure causing rupture of distribution piping or instrument impulse lines. Release of gas into the work area, creating suffocation or displacement hazards. Activation of multiple relief devices leading to uncontrolled discharge. Extended unplanned shutdown of multiple units due to loss of stable supply pressure. Why did it happen — Root causes Cybersecurity controls for remote access to the engineering workstation were inadequate. Pressure control design relied heavily on software logic without sufficient hardwired interlocks. Risk assessments did not consider cyber ‑ initiated manipulation of control valves. Causal factors Operators assumed digital override alarms would trigger immediately but thresholds were too narrow. Critical workstation had outdated authentication and no multi ‑ factor protection. Control room staffing levels limited early detection of slow ‑ trend pressure anomalies. Segmentation between engineering and operations networks was insufficient. What went well Operators noticed the abnormal trend early and escalated quickly. Manual isolation and venting procedures were executed effectively. Relief capacity was available to handle partial surges. Cybersecurity team quarantined compromised systems promptly. Lessons to prevent re ‑ occurrence Cyber intrusions must be treated as credible initiators of physical overpressure events. Pressure ‑ critical systems require physical safety layers that cannot be overridden digitally. Forced commands to valves or actuators should generate immediate alarms and inhibit unsafe movement. Engineering workstations must follow strict access control, patching, and monitoring standards. Operators should verify physical valve response when digital commands behave unexpectedly. Actions

The table layout was visible on a laptop facing outward toward foot traffic. A nearby customer briefly stood behind the employee while waiting for their order and appeared to glance at the screen. The employee noticed the reflection of the bystander in the window and immediately locked the laptop. No confirmed data capture occurred, and the employee relocated to a more private seating area. The incident was later reported as a potential visual ‑ exposure near miss. What could have happened Sensitive internal data could have been viewed, photographed, or recorded. Why did it happen – Root causes Remote ‑ work model lacked clear guidance for public ‑ space device ‑ use risk. Inadequate physical ‑ privacy controls available in the employee’s mobile setup. Security awareness training did not emphasize shoulder ‑ surfing as a visual ‑ exposure hazard. Causal factors Crowded café seating and high customer turnover. Screen brightness left information easily readable from multiple angles. Time pressure to complete work between meetings led to reduced situational awareness. Assumption that working in a casual environment carried minimal data ‑ security risk. Lack of a privacy screen filter on the laptop. Incident was proactively reported, allowing for learning and improvement. Employee moved to a lower ‑ risk environment before resuming work.
